climbs.name: A Farewell to Arms
climbs.fa: J. Holmes, Direct Variation: M. Scott

content.description:
Climb a flaring crack to a horizontal crack below a roof. The original route traverses to the right, around the corner and up another crack to a ledge, then back left to another roof. Moves over the roof past a bolt lead to the top.  
  
 The 5.11c variation (better and more logical climbing than the original line) climbs straight over the first roof to a rock-over onto a sloping ledge. Though slightly run out, multiple falls from the rock-over have been taken without injuries.

Left of Nubbin, Right of Iron Hand
Standard Rack to 3". New 2 Bolt Rappel Anchor. The variation is PG13, while the original route is a little safer.

This route has seen some rockfall and significant movement of boulders at the base, adding a hard 5.10 crux at the bottom of what was a 5.8 route in the guidebook. Climbers looking for an easy trad line should look elsewhere.

Climb the awkward roof on thin pro up to the obvious corner, then much easier climbing to a ledge on top.

Standard rack from 00 to 3". Gear anchor on not-so-great gear.

climbs.name: All that and a Bag of Chips

content.description:
Stick clip or die, 10c grade applies after the first bolt. Hard bouldering below the first bolt up the blank face (V4/5). Once you finally make it past the boulder start, climb the corner with good stances and bad gear until the second bolt. After the bolt, easier and better protected climbing leads up the ledgy corner until it ends, then climb a bit of overhanging face to a two bolt anchor, shared with cabbages and kings. 


Bring the kichen sink - RPs, ball nuts, micro cams will all be helpful. Other than that, a standard rack to #4 camalot.

climbs.name: Angry Birds
climbs.fa: David Bruneau at 12b, FRA Sarah Spurrell at 5.12c

content.description:
This is an excellent, hard climb up one of the cleanest faces in Flatrock. It starts on the ledge on top of P1 of Drop the Mental (5.9 trad).

Start at the left side of the big ledge. Climb to a small ledge 3 feet above the belay ledge and step right to a bolt (easy but a little creepy, optional hand sized cam here, or pre clip the bolt). The climb weaves up the face from here on interesting moves. There is a 2 bolt anchor with no rap hardware after 65 feet of climbing.

Above here is protectable 5.6 climbing leading eventually to the top of the cliff and another anchor, it is 100 feet to the belay from this anchor.


Off Drop the Mental ledge

7 Quickdraws + Anchor. Stick clip or hand size cam to protect getting to the first bolt. Pre-Hanging the draws and pre-clipping the first bolt by rappelling in is a good strategy.

Climb the dark streak between Noggin and Spray Down with some interesting moves around flakes and blocks at the bottom before getting a little trickier towards the top.

Standard rack, gear is good at the bottom but the top section is a little run out.

climbs.name: As Good As it Gets
climbs.fa: J. Holmes, S Russell, K, McClellan

content.description:
One of the better climbs at Main Face, though rarely done. There are 2 possible starts about 8 feet apart, which join each other about 30 feet up. The left start can be belayed from a ledge that is always above the waterline, while the right start must be belayed from a ledge that is often underwater. This route is best done when the tide is very low, or by rappelling down a fixed line on Last Chance. It does not seep as much as Last Chance.

For the left start, climb a thin crack to a sloping ledge and step right to the main crack. Climb this past flakes to a horizontal crack. Traverse left 10 feet to another crack and climb it to a thin flake. Pass this flake and continue up more flakes to a ledge. Continue straight up to another 30 foot crack past a couple overlaps leading to the top of the climb.

The climb is very sustained but offers more good rests than it may appear from below.

Far right end of main face next to last chance
Double Rack from 00 to 1", single from 2" to 3" and many long slings. Ballnuts can be nice at times. Don't bother bringing anything bigger than 3". 2 Bolt anchor at the top with no rap hardware. Need someone to follow and walk-off.

Stick clip the high first bolt, pull the start crux on thin crimps and underclings then climb progressively easier climbing to the top. 0.5 and 0.75 cam for the 5.5 top section. Could use another bolt down low so that the first isn't 16 feet up


Just left of Candy

two or three quick draws, 0.5 - 0.75 cam(s). long stick clip or preclip after lowering from Candy. Rappel anchor shared with Candy

Another climb that has recently gotten harder due to a block falling off the start.

The climb now starts about 8 feet right of the first bolt (Stick Clip) with an easy leftward traverse into a strange, precarious crux sequence to a good hold on the arete up and left of the first bolt. From here some powerful moves get you over the large roof. Once the third bolt is clipped, easy climbing leads to the top.

The unique geometry and traversing on the route can lead to some interesting falls, particularly for the belayer. Careful not to kick your belayer in the head if you blow the moves to the third bolt.

6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor (long cordalette for TR). Stick clip mandatory.

Very short sport route, but has sustained and unique climbing. Stick clip the first bolt, then climb the arete past two more bolts to a ledge. Two bolt rappel anchor on the ledge, or continue up the 5.6 hand crack (gear) on five fingers to another anchor. 

Between Five Fingers and Iron Hand. 
Stick Clip, three bolts, bolt anchor. A few hand-sized cams if continuing to the top of Five Fingers.

Starts on 4 bolts of face climbing through small holds and crimps, might feel like 5.10 around 3rd bolt (crux) until you figure out the beta. Top section contains easier climbing following a widening crack from wide hands to offwidth. Two very different styles of climbing but enjoyable throughout. I found a perfect rack to be 2x #3 and a #4, but could definitely safely climb without a #4, or sew the top section up with a #5, #6. 

There is lots of loose rock above this climb, I trundled all the large stuff I could, and rock shouldn't be disturbed if the rap anchor is used, but caution is always advised. 



At the beginning of Main Face in the blasted section. on the left face of a corner, often shaded when other routes are sunny. 

4 bolts, gear 2"-4", rappel anchpr

Challenging face climbing through the line of well spaced bolts with a high crux.

11 Bolts, Rappel anchor. Bolts replaced in 2019

Start in the corner and follow the bolts left across the face and up. A very popular route for beginner climbers as it is among the easiest routes in Flatrock.

5 bolts and a single piece of gear between the 4th and 5th bolts.

With some rockfall at the start and erosion at the base, this one is a lot harder than 5.10c now. Stick clip the high first bolt and climb an interesting boulder problem over a roof (crux) up into the corner. Some 5.10 climbing up the corner then run it out to the ledge after the third bolt. #2 and 3 camalots can be placed from the large ledge, then a short hand and fist crack leads to the top.


3 quickdraws, stick clip, #2 and #3 camalot and a couple long slings. Gear anchor, or use the bolted anchor to the right on Ataxia

climbs.name: Changing Corner
climbs.fa: FA: unknown, FRA P. Chaisson as "Ozymandias", FRA at 11d, David B?

content.description:
The hanging corner right of Ataxia went through a few changes over the last 20 years. First, the corner had no crack at the back, then a finger crack, then an offwidth, then the block forming the corner fell down completely. The bolts survived this massive rockfall. Additionally, movement of rocks at the base has left a high first bolt, but it can be reached with a 12 ft stick clip. 

In its current state, some easier moves lead to some hard, unusual face climbing with poor footholds past the first two bolts. The route eases up once you reach the hanging corner at the third bolt. Clip the 4th older bolt and run it out to the anchor on Ataxia.



Four bolts, anchors

The best climb at main face? Unfortunately the hardest to access and almost always wet. I may add a belay bolt at the bottom of this to ease access. 
  
 Getting to the base of it is a challenge - I did a traverse in from the left about a foot above the ocean which was much harder than any move on the actual route. Once established at the base of the dihedral, excellent climbing leads up to a roof which is passed on the left side. Continue up cracks until you are a foot below a big bush. An obvious traverse leads right until one can climb up to the sloping ledge. Above this ledge easier cracks with good pro and great exposure lead to the top.

Over the ocean at the far north end of main face
One of the best protected 5.10 trad climbs at main face. Single rack to #2 camalot protected this perfectly but extra finger to hand sized cams could speed things up. Ballnuts are useful but not necessary. Bolt anchor up top but the climb cannot be rappelled with a 60m rope.

Climb a face past seven bolts, with an inobvious cruxy traverse in the middle. The route has been cleaned heavily but staying in line with the bolts is advised - the rock to the right and left of the route is pretty loose.

7 bolts + Anchor.

Climb the wide quartz crack at the right end of the ledge, to a looming, black bulge. Strenuous climbing with great pro leads straight up through the bulge, then a few delicate face moves lead up and right to easier ground. Finish on the big grassy ledge. 

Same ledge over the water as Sea World
Standard Rack to #3 Camalot. Larger pieces (4, 5 and 6 camalot) were used on the FA on the easy bottom section, but are likely not necessary. Gear Anchor.

Climb the face using the thin crack and small holds around it. The climbing is very sustained at the grade with small, fiddly gear and the route is almost always wet but worth the wait.

Standard rack, emphasis on smaller gear.

The obvious crack starting 2/3rds of the way up the face. Getting to it... 
  
 The start is a pumpy corner system that is difficult to protect, with some breakable holds. Once this eases off (later than you may expect) easy climbing leads to a ledge below the crack. The crack is pretty full on. Careful of loose blocks at the top of the crack. 
  
 I enjoyed parts of this route.

Standard rack + ballnuts essential for protecting the bottom. Poor rock above the climb for anchoring, set a redirect and belay off the anchor for "Pog Mahoe"

A two pitch classic. First pitch is 5.9 and is very well protected, making it a popular lead at the grade. The second pitch has some poorly protected easier climbing off the belay but the rest of the pitch has great climbing and pro.

P1. Climb the corner to the roof, then pull the roof on the left and continue to the big ledge with a two bolt rappel anchor. Most people rappel here...

P2. Scary 5.8 climbing up and right from the ledge leads to a short crack with a blade-like chockstone, totems or tri-cams may provide protection on this easier but serious section. Go up this short crack and then make a slabby traverse up and left to the obvious, long vertical crack. Sustained, fun jamming (crux) eventually eases up when the crack becomes a chimney, then ramble up to the top of the cliff to a two bolt anchor. Walk off. 



Standard rack to 3" for the first pitch. Add a #4 camalot for the second pitch, and possibly some doubles in .5 - #1 camalot. A red or brown tri cam may help protect the initial runout on pitch 2.

Start as Yellow Fever and then follow the cracks up and to the left until you meet with the ending of Maggie. Graded 5.10a but an easy trad lead as it is roughly 5.8 until a bolt protected move at the end.

1 bolt and standard rack to 1". Bolted anchor with no rappel hardware, but you can easily rappel from Yellow Fever anchors.

Climb the face with a few moves on small crimps separated by good rests. The route is well protected and usually climbable even if the dark streak is wet.

4 bolts & anchor

An alternate second pitch for Drop the Mental. While the climbing isn't amazing, it's well protected and makes for a nice moderate multipitch over the water when combined with the first pitch of Drop the Mental. Follow the obvious cracks up and left from the first anchor on Drop the Mental, past many ledges. Top out and walk off.



Starts on Drop The Mental Ledge

Standard rack to 3 Camalot. No anchor (tree or gear anchor possible). Verbal communication may be difficult from the top of the climb.

Start in the same place as Yellow fever and then traverse right onto the arete and follow the bolts up using both sides of the arete until you hit the crux right before the end.

Gear to 1" for the start then 5 bolts. Bolted anchor on top.

climbs.name: Fine Line Between Fear and Flying

content.description:
Low bouldery crux under the roof, then sustained with good rests along the way.

Fine Line was long a mid-5.11 test piece, but ever since the lower portion dislodged during heavy rockfall ca. 2014 or 2015 it has been somewhat neglected... but it remains a fine line! Leo van Ulden and Joe Rossiter added the new first bolt ca. 2013.

Starts just left of Operation Recuperation, in the left-facing corner.
Ring bolts, including top anchor

This climb was recently given a heavy cleaning, a bolt anchor and a bolt protecting the beginning section, making it a worthwhile trad lead or toprope for those who have exhausted the classics at Main Face and want to try something different.  
  
 Start on some obvious holds slightly left of the corner and boulder up (easily) to the bolt in the corner. Climb the corner until its end at a ledge to the right. Then climb a jagged hand crack to the top.

Left of Iron Hand
Standard Rack to 3", Good Pro. 2 Bolt Rappel Anchor

Climbing through small holds at the start leads to easier moves in the second half.

The middle route starting from the big ledge.
3 bolts and a single piece of gear before the top out. Rappel anchor on top.

climbs.name: Frank Sinatra
climbs.fa: S. Russell at 5.10a, nobody has led since the "No Freebies" block fell down but it has been toproped

content.description:
This route had a reputation as a sketchy lead before the block forming the first 20 feet fell down. Since the block fell down, there is no gear for the first 20 feet, which is pretty tricky 5.10 climbing which should be bolted as it has not been led in it's current state. The first half of the route is fun as a toprope and I believe it's worth fixing up, possibly as a fully bolted route. 



Nothing at the beginning, then some bad gear, then a bolt, then better gear. No top anchor.

Not a typical Flatrock route. Climb the arête to the right of Medicated Drama Queen. Although appearing blocky this climb was quite solid when established. You may be surprised how overhung it gets in the middle and the crux has the wildest pinch move in Flatrock.  Stay on the arête and out of the chossy dihedral for belayer safety.

Standard rack, 4 bolts and Anchor.

A very exciting climb; while all the hard moves are protected this is not bolted like a modern sport route and some falls off easier sections may be dangerous. Start as per Good Country Lovin', but at the third bolt make a long, runout traverse left and continue up to the fourth bolt. Tricky and engaging face climbing leads past two more bolts, then 20 feet of gear protected climbing with a memorable mantle leads to the top. 


6 bolts, 2.5 - 5" cam for the first horizontal,  0.5 - 1.5" cams for the easy top section. Three bolt anchor

A harder direct start for gabe. Hard, thin climbing similar to Screaming Life past three spaced bolts, then join the fourth bolt of Gabe and continue as per that route. 



Bolts, couple cams for the top of Gabe

Long crack climb over the ocean. Can only be accessed at low tide by hopping along rocks, or by rappelling in, but there is a nice belay ledge above the waterline.

This isn't a 5.10c, we felt that it was easier than a lot of 5.9's at main face. The hollow flakes in the middle of the climb were inspected and cleaned up with a crowbar (August 1st, 2019); the larger flakes could not be removed and seemed well attached, though one should still climb carefully through this section.

Climb an arching crack to a flake system below the roof. Climb past the flakes with pro in adjacent cracks then face climb up to a wide crack (#4 camalot nice here). This crack leads to a grassy ledge with a bolted anchor.

Top out by scrambling up 20 feet right of the bolted anchor, or rappel back down to the ledge



Standard rack to #4 camalot, very well protected. Few extra finger-hand sized cams could be nice because it's long. Bolted rappel anchor shared with Mid Atlantic and Whaleback (28m rappel)

Face climb past three slightly spaced bolts to a rest ledge, then climb the overhanging face above with some good but small gear. Pull the small roof on the right to a large ledge and top out via the wide easy crack to a three bolt anchor. 


three bolts, standard rack with micro cams, bolt anchor

climbs.name: Guillotine
climbs.fa: David Bruneau, Nick Brown, Axel O'Young

content.description:
Excellent crack over the ocean with excellent pro in fine-grained rock. Some crack skills required, but face holds often ease the climbing. The crack starts thin but soon widens to hand size and then wider. The sections where the crack closes off are bypassed using the adjacent finger cracks (crux). Once easy ground is reached, traverse left to the large ledge to avoid the obvious but very chossy overhanging chimney above. From the ledge, 25 feet of easy 5th class up the corner leads to the ledge at the top. Over the ocean north of the other climbs. Access by scrambling through bushes about 50m south of the bunker at the top of the Beamer through a clearing in the trees. Set a rappel off a tree (35-40m) and rappel to a nice ledge 15 feet above the ocean. Standard rack to 3", doubles in hand size cams.
Tree anchor at the top, gear anchor at the bottom which takes many different sizes of cams and nuts.

Climb the face with good holds before moving left around the small roof using horizontal cracks to continue up the face.

At the southern end of crag on the face to the right of the Candy start.
4 bolts are placed for quickdraws. Between bolt 4 and top anchor, some people place a small cam (.75 camalot) in the horizontal crack about 1/2 way between the two.

The boulder-y crux off the ledge is now even more height dependant, now that part of the ledge has fallen off. Feels harder than before but not harder than 12a for someone 6 feet tall. After the crux roof pull, easier but technical face climbing with some incredibly sharp holds eases as you get higher. 

Start under a roof with a small ledge underneath
8 bolts + anchor. Stick clip unless you can solo 5.12

Climb the arete and then continue up the crack to the top.

The right hand end of the big ledge.
1 bolt at the start and standard rack to 2". Rappel anchor on top.

A well-protected mid-route crux makes this an excellent first 5.10 tick for the new leader.

Other than the crux, it's pretty smooth 5.9 sailing, making this route a bit of a "one move wonder."

Located to the right of Pucker Up. 
Ring bolts. Ring bolt anchors accessible from ledge on top.

Somewhat ugly flake/crack system that climbs better than the choss at the bottom would suggest. The route may need some additional cleaning, wearing a helmet is advised as a large hold recently came off the route.

The pro is intermittent and the crack is shallow, making it a poor lead for someone breaking into the grade. Feels harder than Noggin and more sustained.

I enjoyed the climb due to rock-bottom expectations but it is definitely not a great route, at least until it cleans up a bit.

Standard rack - tricams effective for shallow placements. 2 bolt top anchor shared with Wet Caulk

This route goes up the appealing (at least more than its surroundings) hanging dihedral in the middle of the blasted section of Main Face. The climbing is pretty good, but the structure of the rock becomes increasingly disconcerting as you move further off the ground. There is still  loose rock on the pitch, the obvious holds that I easily tore off at the crux suggested that this was likely a FA. It would be a nice climb if given a good cleaning and a rappel anchor 2/3rds of the way up but the rock structure makes me hesitant to do this.  
  
 Starting on a cube shaped boulder, climb the left side of the easy, slabby face up to the hanging corner. Climb the corner past an awkward crux to some unpleasant, gravelly moves onto a grassy ledge. Continue upwards then grovel through the blocky, overhung slot to top out. Belay off some trees. Top out by scrambling over some very slick shrubs - staying on belay here is a good idea.

Way south of all the good routes
Standard rack to 3", doubles of blue mastercam size is a good idea. Ballnuts. Tree anchor.

Start in the flakes under the first bolt and trend right into the corner. Slightly before the roof step left and then up into the horizontal at the roof and traverse left. Go up the small crack on the wall above. 
  
 After the roof there is a ledge to the left of the crack. Although this can be useful if in dire need of a rest it does make the next few moves harder if you go to it.

3 bolts and rack to 2". Rap anchor on top.

Start in thin cracks on blocks before stepping right into the wide crack. A variety of jams and / or face holds in and around the crack can be used to reach the top.

The obvious wide crack around 20ft left of MC Hammer.

Standard rack with bigger gear. You'll want a #5 if it's at your limit, and could even place a #6 if you wanted. Bolt anchor.

Starting at the same corner as candy, follow the dihedral crack and flakes through solid protection. Mostly 5.7ish climbing with a couple cruxy 5.8/5.9- moves in the middle. Top out same anchor as candy.

Right in the corner between candy and Hakuna Matara.
Full rack up to #3. Lots of large nut placements.
Right in the corner between candy and Hakuna Matara.
Full rack up to #3. Lots of large nut placements.

A contrived headpoint route with some fun climbing. Climb the thin crack just left of Drop the Mental, past a bulge into the shallow corner, while trying to avoid the obvious ledges and crack on "Drop the Mental".


Standard rack to 3", with a mix of Rps, ballnuts, tricams, and offset cams should make it safe. Or just toprope it after climbing Drop the Mental.

Originally graded A2 this striking line has recently been done without a hammer without increasing the difficulty. The gear is small but good through the aid pitch and good for the free climbing above. 
  
 Pitch 1 (C2): Aid up the thin seam and through the roof before coming to a ledge with cracks above for a gear belay. 
  
 Pitch 2 (5.9): A few tricky moves off of the belay lead to easier climbing and scrambling to the top. Belay from gear and then scramble up or keep going all the way to the top for trees.

Towards the far end of the face, immediately right of Operation Recuperation.
Rack up to 3" with a couple of larger pieces potentially useful for pitch 2. Lots of micro cams and nuts as well as ballnuts are necessary for the first pitch.

This climb is one of the best and longest routes at Main Face. However it is often wet and can only be accessed at low tide by hopping between boulders, or by rappelling in on a fixed line to the starting ledge.  
  
 Start on a ledge about 8 feet above sea level. Climb a crack on the left end of the ledge, then follow the path of least resistance up and right to a crack in a corner. Climb this crack to a large roof. Pull the roof on the right hand side using a good crack. Easy, blocky climbing then leads to a 2 bolt anchor on top of the cliff.

Far right (north) end of main face
Standard rack to 4", doubles in the .5" to 2" range are a good idea. 2 bolt anchor with no rap hardware, need someone to follow this and walk off.

Climb thin holds straight up the face and to the right side of a small roof before following the bolt line right to the bigger roof and a finishing crux.


Start directly under the small roof to the left of Maggie and Yellow Fever starts.
6 bolts and rappel anchor

Another flatrock route that was hit hard by erosion at the base. Needs at least one new bolt or a 20 foot stick clip.

Climb cruxy opposition moves off the ground, then more face climbing leads to the top anchor, shared with Nubbin.

LONG stick clip, three bolts, and a few cams (finger to hand size) for the horizontals between the second and third bolts. Rappel Anchor.

Climb straight up past bolts and thin holds to reach a pumpy crux moving left through underclings. After the crux move back to the right and finish the balancy but easier moves to the top. Although the route requires a piece of gear it is a simple piece to place so this is often treated as a sport route.

A few feet to the left of the Yellow Fever start.

5 bolts and a piece of gear after the crux (most people use a #2 camalot in an undercling). New top anchor installed at the top of the final corner that allows you to lower from the route, also has a top anchor accessible from above.

Looks like a crack, takes protection like a crack but doesn't really climb like a crack. Start by scrambling up the chossy block to reach solid rock around the crack and follow it to the top.

Standard rack to 1". Rap bolts at the top for anchor

Technical face climbing with interesting exit moves. Stay out of the corner up top for full value.

To the left of the large blocky arete and before the cracks.
8 bolts and anchor. Stick-clip recommended.

Another long, high quality trad climb over the water, with a comfy belay ledge above the waterline.

Start from the same ledge as Garden of Eden and Whaleback. Technical chimney climbing off the ground leads to a long climb up a flake, passing a bolt early on. When the flake finally ends, place a few pieces and face climb diagonally right on thin handholds (crux) to a horn with a bolt next to it. Mantle onto the horn and then follow a thin crack up and left to the top with a bolted rappel anchor.


Over the water, there is a small ledge with many cracks leading upwards, the middle of the crack lines. 
Standard rack from small to #4 Camalot, maybe double up on 3/8" to 1" cams. Well protected without micro pro (RPs and ballnuts) though one could place some of these pieces to sew the climb up.

climbs.name: The Middle of a Choss Pile

content.description:
Awkward climbing past three bolts, then crux out as you try to stuff micro cams into a thin crack to protect the last few feet of the climb. Bolted rappel anchor. The name says it all... in the middle of the blasted section of main face between Hysteria and Flaccid ledge, look for three bolts leading to a thin crack  bolts plus a few very small cams (0 and 1 mastercam, possibly will take something smaller or larger)

It's almost a sport route, you might not deck if you didn't place gear

Another fun climb over the water with great protection. Start 10 feet right of the large ledge. I started from a canoe, but you could also traverse out from the ledge easily. Climb a short crack then climb up and slightly right to another crack via well protected but committing moves (crux). Climb past a small, flat ledge into some flakes that are more difficult than they may appear, then straight to the top via many easier flakes.  

Start 10 feet right of the large ledge above the water
Standard rack to #2 camalot. Well protected

Climb juggy flakes past some ledges to a nice but short finger crack. Popular as a beginner trad lead due to the low grade and good pro.

The first decent looking crack system to the right of Flaccid Ledge
Standard rack to 4", emphasis on 1" to 4" cams. The route has 2 top anchors, one at the edge if you want to set a toprope and another about 20 feet back from the edge and to the right for top belaying. Both are equipped for rappelling.

Sandbag. A boulder-y start (use a cheat stone at the bottom) leads up and right past a (New) bolt to a seam. Climb this seam until it peters out at another bolt, then up the face past the Nubbin to a two bolt rappel anchor.

A few climbs to the left of Candy, in the Iron Hand area at Main Face
Standard rack to 3" - excellent nut placements

Another trad route for the mid-grade range. Cleaned only on lead and just needs a bit of traffic to shake out the scruffy bits. Should clean up well for a nice outing with good protection.  From center of face gain the left trending crack that brings you up to the jagged lightning streak portion. Continue up to triangle alcove above, then past short bulge to stance below the prominent shark fin block. Best to traverse right a bit taking the path of least resistance climbing up to the right of the fin to use it as exit stance.

Southern end
Standard Rack,  natural anchors,tree

climbs.name: One Fine Day
climbs.fa: Jeff Holmes (FA 5.9 variation, Matt Scott & David Bruneau?)

content.description:
An alternate second pitch to Drop the Mental. Climb ledges to the left for about 25 feet, until you reach a big ledge with a hollow-sounding flake that leads to the right. Climb this hollow flake into an obvious dihedral, which is followed to the first of a few roofs. From here there are two options.

The original route (5.10a) turns the roof on the left, then continues up sloping holds on the exposed face to a shallow crack which leads to the top. This option is quite runout, as the last good pro is a few feet below the roof, and there is a considerable amount of difficult climbing after the roof before getting solid gear. Years ago, we trundled a large flake from under the roof, so at least the rock should be solid now.

A safer option is to continue up the corner which arches right, under some roofs, eventually leading to a more vertical corner directly above "Angry Birds". This corner is climbed easily to a two bolt anchor at the top of the cliff. I have toproped, but never led the original route, and have witnessed more than one person climb this variation after attempting to pull the roof on the left and backing off. This variation puts the route at 5.9 and is better protected than the original route, though the climbing is not quite as good.

To the left of Angry Birds, starting on Drop the Mental Ledge
Standard rack, may want some ballnuts if attempting the original route

An excellent alpine-like climb that brings you over varied terrain with a thrilling, airy finish. Don't forget to take in the view.

The crux is right after the "thank-god bolt" as you transition out of the corner.

The route is most often cleaned by a second. The route requires a 70m rope to rappel, however this is not recommended. A 4th class scramble (a very reasonable party may elect to rope up) brings you to Yellow Fever ledge, where a rappel is straightforward.

Starts at the obvious crack just right of "A Fine Line Between Fear and Flying."
Standard rack up to #3, bolted anchor at 35m

Here's another trad option on the menu that flows up the striking arete following its' distinctive V-shaped corner.

Southern end
Standard Rack, natural anchor, tree

A nice face climb that gets easier as it goes. Climb up the jagged feature past two bolts, then climb up some more shelves to another bolt. More face climbing curving left, then back right leads to a sloping ledge below the big roof. Pass through the roof via the obvious wide crack. 

Standard rack to 2". A bit runout from the second bolt to the next horizontal, and some questionable pro in quartz cracks later on. Bolted rappel anchor
Look for a feature that's shaped like a face at the bottom of the wall

Still a classic. This route gained ten additional feet of climbing, two bolts, and a 5.11 crux after the starting ledge fell off.

Starting on a flat block which is occasionally under water, negotiate a blank face past the first bolt to a good edge. This can be done by traversing in from the right, crimping straight up on small holds or with a jump start, all of which are difficult.

More difficult moves over a small roof (second bolt) lead to a rest. From here, traverse left above the lip of the roof and climb the longest, best 5.10 face in Flatrock past many bolts.


This route starts just right of the huge aid roof
11-13 bolts, lower-off anchor. 60m rope reaches the ground, but knot your ends. Stick clip recommended for first bolt

Pull a bouldery move on handjams through the small roof and follow the easy crack to the top.

The roof with a crack at the southern end of the crag.
Standard Rack. Gear anchor at the top, or step right to the bolts on It'll Be Fine.

This route no longer exists. The bottom of the route fell down a long time ago, leaving a blank -looking face and roof below more moderate climbing. May not be worth re-establishing.


three bolts, needs more at the bottom

Often derided as one of the worst bolted routes at main face, this route has a few fun moves and is one of the only fully bolted options at the 5.10- grade in the area, now that "The Price is Right" and adjacent routes have fallen down.

Stick clip the high first bolt (or place a #2 or 3 camalot) then climb up some sidepulls (crux) to a big ledge. Step off the left side of the ledge and head up over more ledges to a bolted anchor 8ft back on a grassy ledge.

4 Bolts, optional hand sized cam OR stick clip, Bolted rappel anchor

A direct start to the route Fifth Element. Start under the roof and pull through some big moves to rejoin the original route in climbing the arete.


8 Bolts & bolt anchor

Nice climb. The buisness is pretty close to bolts. There are two cruxes separated by a good rest. Not nearly as much pucker factor as a lot of routes nearby...

Between "Hakuna Matata" and "Hysteria"
4 bolts + a few pieces of pro (.4 camalot, yellow ballnut if you want pro before first bolt)

Shares a start with Paging Don Kiedick. The route has a bit of a complicated history, I believe the route was first done in 1995, but the first two bolts were then chopped soon after. in 2012 or 2013, the start ledge fell off. Soon after, a new first bolt was added, and the first chopped bolt was replaced with what is now the second bolt. One chopped stud remains, but is the least critical of the bolts on the climb, and can be slung with a nut.  Climb the bouldery start past two bolts. Once past the roof, the climb is nice 5.8 cruise up a long corner past a chopped stud which can be slung with a nut. A sloping ledge is reached, and another good bolt leads left to a crack. Just before the large ledge, which may be guarded by a seagull, one can continue up over the ledge to easier corner climbing, shared with Easy Way Out (5.7). Another option is to traverse left to the anchor on Paging Don Kiedick, which is well protected 5.8 with a large cam (4 or 5 camalot) to protect the middle of the traverse. Using the traverse finish, the climb can be done with a 60m rope (knotted ends). Start as for Paging Don Kiedick 3 bolts, one bolt stud, single rack rack. Good pro is available soon after the chopped stud. 
Traverse finish: big cam (#4 or 5 camalot), lower-off anchor
Original finish: double up on smaller cams

Sustained but reasonable aid climb that goes without a hammer. Frequent marginal placements, but rarely more than one before reaching another good piece. 

Aid up an arching crack (C1-2), then traverse under the big roof via the inset wall with a small ledge (C2). When you reach on the outer face, sustained tricky aid (awkward C2) through smaller roofs leads to a gear belay, where the angle of the wall eases and cracks appear. 5.7 climbing then leads to scrambling to the top of the cliff. The climb may go at a lower grade if you pull some free moves at various points, but we didn't ever leave our aiders because it was freezing cold. 

The line through the roof just right of Jekyll & Hyde
We used a clean aid rack similar to what one would use in Yosemite (Cams to #2 camalot, with doubles of cams to 0.75 plus offset cams and nuts, a handful of micro nuts, and a BD cliffhanger hook)

Start in the same place as Yellow Fever and follow the line up and left as per Dynamic Duo. Before the small roof move across to the right and traverse under the roof to rejoin Yellow Fever and finish.

Standard rack to 1". Rappel anchors at the top.

Thin, thin climbing. 

Spend hours hang-dogging up and down the blank, chalk-free face until you eventually find a viable sequence. Commit the sequence to memory and return once the skin on your fingertips has grown back. The climbing is sustained until the fourth bolt. 

The face climb with hangers (not ring bolts) to the left of Ledge Dweller. There is a small roof above the second bolt.

5 Bolts + Anchor. Too much friction to lower off, need to rappel to clean.

Starting off the ledge, climb the black streak up to the large crack 20 feet up. A long easier climb up the crack leads to a ledge 8 feet before the top. From here it's best to top out via the easy arete on your left (good pro here too) to avoid a loose block in the corner.

Climbs the obvious black streak starting in the middle of a large ledge 8 feet above the waterline.
A few thinner pieces off the deck (red ballnut was nice but not critical), then many cams and nuts of all sizes protect the climb well.

Start in the same place as Yellow fever and after the start traverse right past a large flake. Go up the face to the right of the flake past a small roof and straight to the top. 
  
 There is a large traverse at the start of this so long slings are recommended to avoid rope drag. Also care must be taken when top roping because of the potential swing.

1 bolt and gear to 2". Rappel anchor on top.

Start in the corner under the roof to the right of the Yellow Fever start and climb out around the right side to follow the bolts left and join back up with the main Seascape route.

4 bolts and gear to 2". Rappel anchor on top.

Start on the same block as drop the mental, stepping left over the water to start the climb. Hard and sharp climbing until you pull over the roof, then it eases up a bit. Continue to the main anchor on Drop the Mental ledge. This one has gained a bolt and some additional difficult climbing since the release of the guidebook (the old start ledge separated from the wall and washed away), making it more sustained and higher quality. 


Stick Clip. 6 bolts, bolt anchor

One of the oldest routes at Main Face, and feels stiff for the grade, possibly due to the added length since the boulders at the base washed away. Nowadays, the route starts more or less in the ocean, with the best belay boulder accessible only at mid to low tide. An anchor has now been placed directly over the climb (July 28th, 2019) which allows you to toprope the route and prevents the rope from running through a sharp crack, which had a reputation for damaging ropes.

Step over from a protruding belay boulder and climb to the new first bolt (stick clip here would be useful). From here, three older (but still bomber) 1/2 inch bolts lead to the left edge of Drop the Mental Ledge where there is now a two bolt anchor. The hard climbing is well protected by the bolts, though the easier terrain on the route can feel a bit run out.

under the left end of Drop the Mental ledge
Four bolts, anchor, small cam for beginning or stick clip first bolt.

Climb straight up through crimpy holds and a crux after the second bolt.

The leftmost route on the large ledge.
3 bolts and rappel anchor. A little sketchy if you were to fall immediately before the third bolt, but attentive belaying should keep you safe.

A new start has been added to this route, bringing the climbing down to 5.10d again. Start up the first two bolts of Over Easy and traverse right along a rail to reach the second bolt of the original climb. Alternatively, stick clip the high first bolt of the original climb and climb thin 5.12 down and right of the bolt. Once the start is negotiated, closely bolted, enjoyable climbing leads to a lower-off anchor below the big boulder.

10 bolts, lower off anchors, Stick Clip mandatory for the direct version, not as necessary for the traverse in

A bold, sandbagged route which includes some of the best and worst climbing at Main Face. With multiple cruxes that feel like 5.11 and some potentially dangerous climbing, this route is commonly, if not always, done as a headpoint or toprope. Care should be taken even on toprope as the rock in the easier section of the climb is thought to be unstable.

Boulder up to a high first bolt. Typically people have done this unprotected, but a crash pad or stick clip is an option. Once the bolt is clipped, go either straight up or diagonally left, both options go at a similar difficulty. At this point, mount the sandy, loose blocks with gear in behind them (5.8R) to arrive at the base of the overhanging, splitter finger crack. Climb this amazing crack to the top.

Standard rack, including micro cams. Bring some extra finger sized pieces for the gear anchor.

Climb the arete on interesting rock past closely spaced bolts. A fun warm up and an easy way to set up top-ropes on other climbs. 

To the right of Flaccid ledge, right of Noggin, left of Pog Mahoe
6 Bolts + 2 Bolt Rappel Anchor

Climb the blocks to the right of the obvious crack. The route traverses along the roof and finishes the same as MC Hammer.

Standard rack with bigger gear (up to #5 camalot) & anchor

Another sport route for the easy section of main face. This one climbs past seven bolts following flakes and good holds to the left of Noggin.

Usually the water streak doesn't interfere much with the climbing, as you can climb to the right of the streak without increasing the difficulty by much.

7 bolts + anchor (rappel). Cordalette anchor (6 foot arms).

Excellent climbing up some of the best rock at main face. Was cut from the guidebook. Start on ledge that is accessed by hopping along rocks past Last Chance. Can only be accessed at low tide from below, or by rappelling in at any time, but the route does not seep like the other routes at this end of the face. The climb traverses off the ledge on a horizontal crack then up a thin crack to a small roof. Traverse under this roof then up the obvious corner/flake feature. Climb this feature until easier flakes are reached, then straight up to the triangular ledge that protrudes from the wall. Step left to a crack once standing on this narrow fin, then climb this crack to a big grassy ledge (belay). Easy 5th class leads up to the east coast trail past here, roping up is optional. Right of Garden of Eden at the far right end of main face. Goes up to an obvious protruding "Shark Fin" Double set of cams to #1 Camalot, 1x #2 camalot, nothing larger needed. Lots of large nuts, Ballnuts very useful.

Bolted Anchor shared with two other routes.

The classic route at Flatrock, and sharing it's start with many other routes it can get pretty crowded (by NL standards) around the base. 
  
 The route follows an obvious corner system with a couple of distinct reachy cruxes. The gear is good and plentiful but can only be placed in specific locations. 
  
 Unfortunately due to the movement of rocks around the base the start of the route is a little tougher now and the first piece of protection is almost 20 feet from the ground.

Standard rack to 1" and 1 bolt. Rappel anchors on top.

The largest part of Flatrock containing the vast majority of climbs including the longer routes and a few two pitch climbs towards the northern end. The area receives morning sun and the temperature can change dramatically without the sun if the wind is blowing.

A unique feature of the crag is that the boulders at the bottom of the routes shift around from season to season. This can result in unusually high (or low) first bolts on routes. The motion of the boulders also has the effect of rounding off the holds at the bottom of the routes, resulting in a crux at the beginning of many of the routes. A stick clip is mandatory here, and don't hesitate to stick clip the second bolt if ground fall seems likely when climbing past the first.   

While a scramble from the trail above exists which can be used to set topropes on routes near Yellow Fever, there is some loose rock present which could be dislodged onto groups below. It is recommended to climb Candy (5.7 sport) to set toprope anchors on routes from MC Hammer to Hysteria, and to climb Spray Down (5.7+ sport) to reach anchors from Flaccid to Seascape.
